regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Novel deep learning-based solution for identification of prognostic subgroups in liver cancer/crops_ordered/page_11/region_2_text.png
regions.text:
Using the pre-processed omics data before scaling, significant mRNA and methyla-
tion features consistently identified by Lpsc were visualised in prognostic clusters using
heatmaps. Heatmaps were produced using Seaborn [22] with expression shown as a
z-score, which is a representation of standard deviations of expression of each gene from
the mean. Scale was limited to —3+3 using vmin and vmax in the clustermap function
in Seaborn to improve the visualisation of differences between the prognostic clusters
being presented.

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Novel deep learning-based solution for identification of prognostic subgroups in liver cancer/crops_ordered/page_11/region_3_title.png

/mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Novel deep learning-based solution for identification of prognostic subgroups in liver cancer/crops_ordered/page_11/region_4_title.png

/mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Novel deep learning-based solution for identification of prognostic subgroups in liver cancer/crops_ordered/page_11/region_5_text.png
regions.text:
Cluster quality metrics were compared between models (Table 2). The clusters obtained
by the baseline models BCE and MSE had lower Silhouette scores (0.18—0.31), indicat-
ing poorer cluster quality, i.e. more heterogeneous. For BCE and MSE, the number of
significant bottleneck features to be used in clustering following filtering, as identified by
the univariate Cox models, was quite low and ranged from 11 to 21 out of the bottleneck
dimension of 100. By comparison, some of the highest Silhouette scores were achieved
by Lec, demonstrating that the k-means inspired loss produced better quality clusters
compared to the other losses. This provided greater confidence in sample assignment to
clusters by the Lpc and indicated that they comprised of more homogeneous and conse-
quently more biologically meaningful groupings. For loss functions using L¢, the bottle-
neck layer was clustered according to group labels derived after each epoch. For Lpyc and
Lysc, the Silhouette score of the bottleneck improves as epochs increase (Fig. 4). With
the heavy influence of L; the ascent of the Silhouette score in Lpc (Fig. 4A) is smoother
than Lesc (Fig. 4B). The Silhouette score steadily rises with continued training with Lec,
thereby indicating a continuous improvement in sample assignment for both models.

regions.text:

ters identified by the best run using the log-rank test P-value for each loss function were

/mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Novel deep learning-based solution for identification of prognostic subgroups in liver cancer/crops_ordered/page_11/region_9_text.png
regions.text:
Asummary of the highest and lowest Silhouette scores and log-rank P-values across 10 runs for each loss function. The log-
rank P-values for MSE and BCE varied between significant and non-significant, whereas the survival-based losses produced
the lowest log-rank P-values. Silhouette scores for MSE and BCE remained below 0.4, indicating low confidence in group
assignments whereas the clustering-based loss Lp- was able to produce the highest Silhouette scores, indicating high
confidence in group assignments
